Fields.DialogueText: Canarias, I assume you are aware of our new orders?
Sí, Capitán. Escort duty, a waste of my talents.

Fields.MenuText: No argument here. Escort missions are the worst, but orders are orders.
Without international shipping, our war against the Morganas would fail. As mundane as it may seem, these missions are essential.
Those transports are depending on us to protect them. We have a duty to keep them safe, like it or not.

Fields.DialogueText: Por supuesto. Orders must be followed. But if we are to achieve victory over the Morganas, it will not be through patrolling shipping lanes.
Better we chase down the Morganas than wait for them to come to us. If our enemies are too busy running from us, they will have no time to threaten the merchants.
Indeed, and I intend to fulfill that duty. However, would it not be more effective to eradicate the threat rather than waiting for our enemy to strike first?
You have a point, but taking the fight to the Morganas would require us finding them first. We can't sail the oceans freely while our shipping lanes are under attack.
If we do not take the initiative, we will never have a chance at victory. Command must be brought to understand this.
Think of it this way. Our shipping lanes are the most likely place the Morganas will strike. If we're looking to send them running, this is probably the best place to start.
True enough, Capitán.
Capitán! I sighted a Morgana strike force. They're trying to sneak around us and attack the merchant convoy.
Plot an intercept course! We have to run them down before they reach the convoy!
Heh, you think you are the predator, Bruja del Mar, but you are my prey now!
@BATTLE
Morganas sighted up ahead, Capitán.
We have to keep these shipping lanes clear. Don't let them get away.
@BATTLE
It seems our merchant convoy has reached port safely. We just received a message extending their appreciation. You impressed them, Canarias.
I am rather impressive, Capitán, especially to the eyes of a merchant.
Most people still haven't seen a Belle in action. You may not realize it, but you and your sisters are something of celebrities around the world.
¿Estamos famosas? Well, I am a flagship. It is fitting for people look to me as a symbol. But you should be famous as well, Capitán. Your leadership guides us to victory.

Fields.MenuText: I can do without fame. I'm here to do my duty, not sign autographs.
Well, I'm sure I'll be a footnote in the history books someday. Probably in a chapter detailing your many exploits.
Maybe we can become a famous couple like Bonnie and Clyde, or King Ferdinand and Queen Isabella.

Fields.DialogueText: You are a leader, Capitán, it is only natural for you to have followers, both in and outside of the navy.
Ha! You jest, Capitán. If anyone is deserving of a chapter in a history book, it is you. One detailing how you drove back the Morgana menace!
A couple? You mean like Charlemagne and Roland facing down the Moors?
We'll just have to deal with any fame as it comes. We are assuming it won't be posthumous, after all.
Do not worry about that, Capitán. I will not let you fall, in battle or in the tabloids.
I'm not looking to become a politician. Once this war is over, I am more than happy to sink back into anonymity.
I am not sure I would let you disappear, Capitán. If I am to be a celebrity, I will want you at my side for the photos.
Ha! I think you underestimate just how incredible you Belles are. Humans have had military officers for a long time, but we have never seen anything like you.
I suppose it would depend on the book, then.
Hmph, more like Don Quixote and Sancho Panza, I guess.
I am not a farmer, Capitán. Although, if you wish to call yourself delusional, I will not stop you.
It is nice to be on the hunt again, Capitán. Merchant shipping may be important, but in times of war, a cruiser like myself must be free to pursue her foes.
I haven't heard of any Belles on civilian ships. I wonder if war is just part of your nature.
I can only speak for myself, Capitán, but it is certainly part of mine. I could never be a merchant vessel... not in this century, anyway.
Oh? You think you could be a merchant ship if you were built in the past?
During the Age of Sail, it was the merchant galleons that made España the greatest power in the world. Those ships faced down pirates and explored the unknown.

Fields.MenuText: So you could be a merchant ship as long as you could keep your cannons.
The Age of Sail is romanticized. I'm sure the actual sailors didn't think of their work as adventurous.
There is something beautiful about the thought of being one of those early explorers, able to chart undiscovered waters and lands for the first time.

Fields.DialogueText: Heh. Surely you did not think I would give those up, did you, Capitán?
Perhaps the common sailors did not, but I do, Capitán. Out here on the water and with the wind, I am filled with a sense of purpose and adventure.
They were alone in the ocean, with only one another to rely upon. They had no idea what they would find at the end of their journey. What an exciting time to live.
Are you sure you wouldn't prefer to be a Ship of the Line?
No. I am a cruiser, not a battleship. I need the freedom to sail the open seas. Besides, the Canary Islands were home to a great deal of merchant shipping during those days.
So you would be at home.
Capitán, I have detected Morganas approaching.
Looks like we have to get back to today's problems. Take us forward, Canarias.
@BATTLE
Canarias, there's something in the mess hall I would like you to see.
The mess hall? Very well, Capitán...
All set, Captain. Here it is.
What is this?
I know you enjoy bananas, but I've never seen you eat one with ice cream. The crew and I thought we should change that. This is a banana split sundae.
Oh... um, gracias. It seems so... decadent.
Hurry and try it before it melts!
Very well, one bite…
¡Tan dulce, tan delicioso, es increíble!
I knew she'd like it, Captain. Even a Belle can't resist a good sundae.

Fields.MenuText: I'm glad you like it, Canarias. The crew and I wanted to thank you for all you do for us. A sundae might not be enough, but it is something.
Looks like next time we hit port, we had better stock up on ice cream.
Why do I feel like we opened Pandora's box?

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, no, Capitán, this is more than enough. I never knew such a dessert existed!
Por favor, not on my account, Capitán. Although, if the crew were to eat such a dish again, I would be happy to join them.
Ha! It is too late to close the lid now, Capitán. Thank you all for this wonderful new dessert!
Attention, Morganas sighted in the area. All crew to stations!
Just like those Brujas del Mar to interrupt dessert! Well, they shall find my cannons especially painful today!
Canarias, don't eat so quickly! You'll get…
Ow!
... brain freeze.
@BATTLE
Capitán, have you ever wondered what the next evolution in naval warfare will bring?
If I don't say "more heavy cruisers,” will I get in trouble?
Heh. You can say whatever you like, Capitán. But I cannot guarantee your safety.

Fields.MenuText: If this war has demonstrated anything, it is that Belles are the future of naval warfare.
Submarines and aircraft carriers have changed the face of naval war. In the future, I expect most fleets will never see each other when they engage.
Hmm... well, we have figured out how to fight on land, sea, in the air, and even under the sea. I expect the next place we'll go is up into outer space.

Fields.DialogueText: I am flattered, Capitán, but how can we be the future when you still do not understand how we came to be?
Who would seek such a sterile and impersonal war? Where is the glory in cowering behind the horizon and never facing your foe?
Space? Well, I suppose someday it may happen.
Once we get an idea in our heads, we humans tend to find a way to make it happen. What makes you ask?
I realized that, in the future, my hull will become as obsolete as the wooden ships of the past. Someday, I will be decommissioned.
Perhaps, but we don't decommission soldiers the same way we decommission ships. You are more than a warship, Canarias, I would never let them send you to a scrapyard.
Gracias, Capitán, but this is the only life I have known. I would not know what to do if I became obsolete.
You wouldn't be obsolete to me.
Captain, we have Morganas spotted ahead.
Looks like we have to get back to the present task at hand. We can discuss the future later.
Another time, then.
For now I am a premier warship, a fact these Morganas shall appreciate shortly.
@BATTLE
I do not think I would like fighting in space. I would miss the feel of the waves and the sound of the wind.
Capitán, enemy sighted approaching from the south!
@BATTLE
Excellent work, Canarias. Let's resume our course.
Capitán, when we discussed the future of warfare, you mentioned that I would not be obsolete to you... what did you mean by that?

Fields.MenuText: Well, uh… I meant that it would always make sense to, uh, have you around.
*Ahem* I simply meant that I would never consider an old friend to be an "obsolete” friend.
I really... I really like you?

Fields.DialogueText: Oh... I suppose it would always make sense to have you around as well, Capitán.
I am not an old friend yet, Capitán. I would thank you to remember that!
Are you asking me?
Did you think about what you would do if you were retired?
Retired? I'll admit I have never really thought of a future beyond fighting, but perhaps there is a place for me outside of war. Would you help me find it, Capitán?
I would be honored to.
I like the idea of speaking about the future with you, Capitán. There is something... hopeful about it.
Yes. This war has kept us from moving forward for a long time, but just thinking about the future... well, it makes it seem less far off.
Let us forge ahead together then, Capitán.
Capitán, we have heavy fog ahead.
Torpedoes in the water, Captain!
Ambush! Canarias, hard to port!
@BATTLE
Canarias, what are you doing out here? Are you all right? You broke a string on your timple.
Oh? So I did... Forgive me, Capitán, my thoughts are distracted.
It's clear you have something on your mind. I would be happy to lend an ear.
*sigh* It is my sister, Capitán, Baleares. I often find myself thinking of her after a battle... thinking of the night she sank.
I'm sorry, that must have a terrible night.
I still have not forgiven her.
Forgiven Baleares? For what?
For sinking! For failing her duty... for failing me.

Fields.MenuText: Canarias, if your sister was sunk in battle, how can you blame her for that?
Failing you? What did your sister owe you?
A soldier's duty sometimes involves risking their life. Death is not failure, it is sacrifice.

Fields.DialogueText: She was the best warship in the Spanish fleet! Our squadron's flagship! No other ship should have been able to touch her, let alone sink her.
That... that is not the point, Capitán, she was our best ship! Her loss was a blow to our national pride!
She had a duty to bring victory! Instead her death brought shame. That is not sacrifice, it is betrayal.
Don't you think you are being a little too hard on your sister?
I am done talking about her!
Canarias! She left her timple…
Captain, Morgana fleet spotted!
@BATTLE
Canarias, I know it's a painful subject, but we need to talk about Baleares.
Why speak of the dead, Capitán? She is gone.
Because, clearly, you have not let her go. Come on, let's find somewhere we can speak in private.
It's quiet enough over here. Now what?
I want to hear about the night Baleares sank.
*sigh*
Very well, Capitán. Our squadron had been tasked with escorting Italian transports when we stumbled upon a Republican force in the dead of night.
After a brief exchange, we broke contact. Our admiral wanted to wait until morning when our superior firepower could be brought to bear, but the Republicans had other plans.
They changed course to follow us. We spotted their cruisers and began firing, but we didn't see their destroyers until it was too late.
Baleares was right in front of me when she was struck. I had to turn hard just to avoid hitting her sinking stern... that was the last time I saw her.
I don't see where Baleares failed you or Spain.
After that night, I was alone. I was the premier warship of the Spanish fleet, the only heavy cruiser of my class. Because Baleares fell, I had to be invincible... for España.

Fields.MenuText: You had to be invincible, even though you saw your sister sink.
You're not alone, Canarias. Not while I'm here.
Your sister didn't fail, Canarias, and neither did you.

Fields.DialogueText: España was still fighting a civil war. It needed a symbol of stability, of indestructibility. As their new flagship, that responsibility fell to me. Then as now, I was not allowed to fail.
I keep thinking about what would have happened if Baleares had survived that night. Would my sister have awakened too? The Morganas wouldn't have been prepared for the likes of her.
I was helpless, Capitán. My sister was sinking in front of me, and I could do nothing. Not even avenge her... and now she is gone, and I remain.
Canarias, I never met Baleares, so I can't speak for her. But I've known you for a while now, and you are not perfect.
Capitán, that is...
I've seen your flaws, your mistakes, your weaknesses, and I'm sure I'll see more in the future.
Perhaps it was foolish for you to have brought me into the fleet, then.
I don't regret it.
You don't? But what if I fail you, Capitán?
I don't believe in you because I think you're perfect, I believe in you and trust you because I know even when you do fail, you never stop trying.
Thank you for your faith in me, Capitán.
I'm not sure I can ever measure up to what she was.
How am I supposed to shoulder España without her?
Heavy fog sighted!
@BATTLE
Captain, we have new orders from Command. The Spanish government is asking to have a dignitary come aboard the ship to act as an observer.
An observer? Well, I suppose it is their ship. Who is this dignitary?
A Mr. Ciro Rosales Garcia, Captain.
Do we know anything more about him?
I'm afraid not, Captain. Just that he is a member of the Falange party and a representative of Spain.
I'm afraid I have no knowledge of Señor Rosales either, Capitán, but it would be nice to have a proper Spanish gentleman aboard.

Fields.MenuText: Wait, what's the matter with who we have on board already?
Politicians should be off shaking hands and kissing babies, not taking up space on a warship during combat.
I'm sure he will be delighted to meet you, Canarias.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, nothing, Capitán. I simply meant that it has been a long time since I have had a statesman aboard. It will be a welcome change of pace, that is all.
Really now, Capitán. I am sure he will be no trouble at all. It makes sense that España would wish to observe me in battle first hand.
That is kind of you to say, Capitán, but I think he will be more delighted to meet you. You are the one who has led us to our many victories over the Morganas.
Well, either way, it looks like we will have a little time to prepare for his arrival.
Please leave everything to me, Capitán. I will see to it that everything is in order for Señor Rosales' arrival.
Very well.
Canarias, I think you're missing something.
My timple! Gracias, Capitán.
I had it restrung for you. It didn't seem right for you to be without it.
I had not thought to play it for some time now, Capitán.
I noticed. For humans, music can give voice to pain or emotion in a way words simply can't manage on their own. Maybe you should try writing a song about Baleares.
I am not sure I would know what to write, Capitán.
Just a suggestion, not an order. We never forget those we've lost, but we do learn to honor the memory of the fallen and live on. Write something to honor your sister.
Capitán, you have been very kind to me. I know you are concerned for the wellbeing of your crew, but why do you work so hard to help me?

Fields.MenuText: You're a member of my crew. If I see you're in need help, I'm going to help you.
Because when I see you hurting... well, I hurt too. And when I see you smile…
I guess I'm just a sucker for a damsel in distress.

Fields.DialogueText: Is that all? Do you offer every sailor aboard this vessel the same amount of support you offer me?
You smile too?
A damsel? Well, do not get too comfortable on your horse, caballero. I am not a princess to be locked in a tower, waiting for her knight in shining armor.
Yes, well...
Never mind, Capitán. I think we should get back to winning this war.
Good idea.
@BATTLE
What are you doing over there? This isn't a sailboat.
No, Captain. I'm stitching a dress.
A dress? That doesn't look regulation, sailor.
Yes, Captain. I mean no, Captain. It's uh... it's for Canarias, Captain.
Gangway!
Excuse me?
Oh, Captain! I'm sorry, I didn't realize it was you.
Where are you off to in such a hurry?
Canarias wants the whole ship cleaned before the dignitary's arrival, Captain.
There you are! Have they finished washing the linens yet? I want my signal flags washed as well. And what about... oh, Capitán, what are you doing here?

Fields.MenuText: Standing in the way, apparently.
You're not overworking my crew, are you, Canarias?
Don't you think you're going a bit overboard for this Mr. Rosales?

Fields.DialogueText: Forgive me, Capitán. I just want to make sure everything is ready before Señor Rosales arrives.
Oh no, Capitán. They volunteered to help. Besides, it is only a little more cleaning than their normal duties.
I am still the flagship of the Spanish Fleet, Capitán. It would not do for Señor Rosales to see me at less than my best. It would tarnish Spanish pride.
Well, I'll leave you to it, then.
Attention, Morganas sighted in the area. All hands report to battle stations.
They attack now!? If those Brujas del Mar so much as splash salt water on my deck I will hit them with enough shells to sink them under the sheer weight!
Okay, then. Let's get to the bridge.
@BATTLE
Oh, Canarias, you look wonderful.
Gracias, Capitán. It would not do for a Dueña del Mar to greet a Spanish dignitary looking anything less than her best.
We have confirmation from the Spanish transport, Captain. They should be in sight soon.
¡Maldito sea! Capitán, we have Morganas inbound!
Everyone to battle stations! We can't let the Morganas get anywhere near the transports.
@BATTLE
¡Cielos! I look terrible. How am I to supposed to present myself to Señor Rosales looking like this?
If Mr. Rosales has any brains, he will understand your duties must come before your appearance.
I hope so, Capitán. We shall find out soon, here he is.
Mr. Rosales, on behalf of the INPF, I would like to welcome you aboard. You will have to forgive the state of our ship, we were in battle before you arrived.
There is nothing to forgive Capitán. I understand you chased away a group of Morganas that were hunting our transports.
Señor Rosales, I am very pleased to make your acquaintance. If you are in need of anything while you are aboard please let me know.
The Belle speaks? How interesting. I must admit, Capitán, I didn't expect her to be so... feminine.
Why yes, the Belle does speak. Be grateful she also knows how to bite her tongue!

Fields.MenuText: I'm sure he meant no harm, Canarias. Most people have never met a Belle before.
It seems our dignitary needs to brush up on his manners.
What exactly did you expect, Mr. Rosales?

Fields.DialogueText: A gentleman always remembers his manners, especially when encountering an unfamiliar situation.
I suppose Señor Rosales does not think common courtesy need apply to Belles!
It seems he was expecting a mute machine, Capitán. So sorry to disappoint you, Señor Rosales.
She seems upset. Can Belles get angry, Capitán?
Oh yes, and you have just succeeded in making her so, Mr. Rosales. Let's get you settled into your quarters, and then you can think of how to apologize.
Capitán, may I speak with you for a moment?
Go ahead, Mr. Rosales.
I want you to understand I meant no offense to Canarias, Capitán. It seems I was improperly briefed as to the nature of these Belles.
I appreciate that, Mr. Rosales, but I am not the one you should explain this to.
I know, but Canarias will not let me speak to her. I cannot make an apology if she will not listen. Would it be possible for you to intercede on my behalf?

Fields.MenuText: That depends. Spain already receives regular reports on Canarias' activity. Why are you really here, Mr. Rosales?
You dug yourself into this hole, Mr. Rosales, I'm not going to jump in with you.
I'll speak with her, but understand that Canarias is going to come to her own conclusions about you, Mr. Rosales.

Fields.DialogueText: What you say is true, Capitán, but as you can see, there is a great deal that has not been communicated in the reports we receive.
I am not here to antagonize Canarias, Capitán, I assure you. I had hoped for a cooperative relationship with you.
I am beginning to understand that, Capitán. I promise I will not repeat this mistake.
Is that all, Mr. Rosales?
I do not wish to deceive you, Capitán. I am not here just to observe Canarias, but also to observe you as well.
Me?
Canarias represents the future of naval supremacy for Spain. You must understand she is irreplaceable in the eyes of my government.
There are some concerns about the danger you have put her in.
Sorry to interrupt, Captain. Canarias is detecting Morganas nearby.
Thank you. I promise you we will continue this conversation, Mr. Rosales.
@BATTLE
Capitán, won't you join me?
Certainly. There is a nice breeze out here. It's almost enough to make you forget you are in a warzone.
Someday, perhaps we may enjoy it in peace.
Ciro asked me to talk to you about receiving his apologies.
Do you think I should? I was going to let him suffer for at least a few more days.
He also mentioned that he was here to observe me as much as you. It seems the Spanish government has some misgivings about the level of risk I have exposed you to.
You must be joking! How can they doubt your command? Without you, our casualties would be much higher.

Fields.MenuText: It's not casualties they are worried about, it's you. They don't want to lose you.
Do you think I put you in too much danger, Canarias?
Armchair generals always think they know better than those in the field.

Fields.DialogueText: I see. This is not a war España can afford to sit out. If we do not defeat the Morganas, all nations will be hostages within their own borders.
I have never thought this, Capitán. I am a soldier, it is my duty to serve, and that means putting myself in danger. I would not forgive you if you tried to keep me from that duty.
Then I am glad Señor Rosales is here. Surely you will be exonerated once they understand the threat we face.
Anyway, I thought you should know. If you want to let Mr. Rosales apologize, I'll let him know where to find you, but don't let him off the hook for my sake.
Not at all, Capitán. I will find him at once. I would not wish for my obstinance to reflect poorly on you. Still, it is a shame to stop his suffering so quickly.
Heh. At any rate, what do you say we get back to hunting Morganas?
Certainly, Capitán. Just be sure to ask the Morganas not to put me in too much danger...
Now that just wouldn't be fair.
It seems we must show España that the Morganas are the ones who should be afraid. ¡Vamonos, Capitán!
@BATTLE
Morganas sighted off the port side!
@BATTLE
I must say, Canarias, you fight magnificently. As a Spaniard, seeing you in battle against the Morganas makes my heart swell with pride.
I hope you will convey these feelings to the Spanish people, Señor. It is they I fight for.
I shall, but we must find a way to present you to the Spanish people in person. Your face should become synonymous with nationalist pride.
I am attached to the ship, Señor. I would be unable to present myself on Spanish soil.
Yes, of course, I read as much. However, as I'm sure you are aware, there was much missing from our reports on Belles.

Fields.MenuText: I'm glad to see the two of you are getting along.
Looks like you've found an admirer, Canarias. Mr. Rosales sounds like he wants to plaster your picture all over Spain.
Once the Morganas are defeated, there will be time enough for parties and politics. In the meantime, Canarias should stay focused on our mission.

Fields.DialogueText: Sí, Capitán. Señor Rosales made quite the charming apology. He even managed to find flowers.
Señor Rosales speaks to the concerns of España, Capitán. Is it wrong for me to use my fame to better the lives of my people?
I am focused, Capitán. But my duties extend beyond this war. I fight for the future of España, not just the present.
Ah, Capitán. Thank you for speaking with Canarias on my behalf. I am putting together an informal dinner, and I would like both of you to attend.
Is this a working dinner?
Ha! This is how politicians work, Capitán. But do not worry, I am not setting an ambush for you.
Very well. You are our guest. I can't very well refuse your invitation.
Good, I'll let you know when. In the meantime, won't you show me around the ship, Canarias?
Of course, Señor.
Captain, enemy fleet sighted!
@BATTLE
I hope you enjoyed the dinner, Capitán. If every night was so decadent, I think I could get used to navy life.
It was lovely, Señor Rosales. A fine meal to compliment a fine victory.
Please, Canarias, call me Ciro.
As you wish, Ciro.
Mr. Rosales, you told me you were here to observe my command of Canarias. You have witnessed several engagements now. Have you drawn any conclusions?
I have indeed, Capitán. It is clear enough to me you are an excellent officer, and the way you fight with Canarias is a wonder to behold.
The capitán and I have been through much together, Ciro, it is only natural that we should come to share a close bond.
Certainly, my dear. However, I have read through past mission reports and noticed that there were times when there appeared to be discord between you.

Fields.MenuText: It took time for Canarias and I to build a working relationship, as it would any commander and subordinate.
Any "discord” has been dealt with, Mr. Rosales. Canarias has been exemplary in battle, and I trust her with my life.
If you're looking for dirt, you'll have to keep digging, Ciro. There is nothing in those reports that could paint me as incompetent.

Fields.DialogueText: Although I am a warship, I was never trained to be a soldier. I am sure my own immaturity was the cause of any discord, Ciro.
The capitán speaks the truth, Ciro. Moreover, the capitán has always shown incredible ability against the Morganas. Any earlier problems must be laid at my own feet.
Forgive the capitán's manners, Señor. However, if there is any question of incompetence, please know those earlier reports only reflect poorly on myself, not the capitán.
It seems you misunderstand me. I take no issue with the capitán's command. I am only curious as to the nature of your relationship.
What do you mean by that?
My government understood Belles to be the personification of warships, but you do not treat Canarias like a warship, Capitán. You treat her like a lady.
And what is wrong with that? I am the dueña de la nave, Señor.
It is personal. A warship has no feelings, opinions, or loyalty my dear. As I have been made quite aware, you do. You are loyal to your capitán, and that is problematic.
I do not understand.
The civil war is over, Mr. Rosales. We're in the middle of another war, one that requires cooperation and trust, not suspicion.
The capitán would never order me to break trust with the Spanish people, Señor!
Perhaps not, but you understand how recent history would cause us some apprehension.
Forgive me, I have spoiled the evening with politics, we'll discuss this another time.
Oh, hello Canarias. I didn't expect to see you here.
We have often spent time together on the bow, Capitán. Why should it be strange for me to come here?
I would have expected you to be with Mr. Rosales. The two of you seem inseparable lately.
Ciro is taking a nap. I thought I might watch the waves, but I am glad to find you here, Capitán.
I see…
Capitán? Is something wrong?

Fields.MenuText: You spend so much time with Ciro, that I've missed you a bit.
What's he like? When it's just the two of you, I mean.
Is there something going on between you and Ciro?

Fields.DialogueText: Missed me? But I have not gone anywhere. I cannot leave the ship!
Ciro is a refined and charming gentleman. Why do you ask?
¿Qué? Something between us? I really do not understand what you mean, Capitán, but it seems I have upset you.
Never mind... Forget I said anything.
I have to spend time with Ciro, Capitán. He must be made to understand that there is nothing between us that could be a threat to España.
Capitán, are you... are you jealous of me and Ciro?
Captain! Sorry to interrupt, Captain. We have reports of a mist forming close by. Command wants us to investigate.
Right. Let's get up to the bridge.
@BATTLE
All hands to battle stations, enemy inbound!
@BATTLE
Canarias? I thought I heard your timple, and I wanted to... oh, Mr. Rosales. I didn't mean to interrupt.
Not at all, Capitán, please join us. Canarias plays so masterfully she deserves a better audience than I can provide.
Canarias? Am I interrupting?
Of course not, Capitán. Ciro asked if you had assigned me other duties beyond fighting. I told him you suggested that I play a concert for the crew.
Canarias is a lady of many talents.
She is. Are you wondering if she can be induced to perform actions outside the scope of battle?
Ha! My goodness, but you are insightful, Capitán. I can see why the Morganas have so much trouble with you.
I am afraid I fail to understand. Would you mind sharing your insight, Capitán?
The capitán has deduced that I am investigating how easily you can be compelled to take part in activities outside the range of your duties, Canarias.
Compelled? Does giving a simple concert give you more cause for apprehension, Ciro!?
I am not concerned with what you have done, Canarias, I am concerned with possibilities. If you can be convinced to hold a concert, than why not a political rally?

Fields.MenuText: Perhaps you should be concerned with reality, and not possibility, Ciro. I have never asked anything of Canarias that could be considered against Spain's interests.
You're making it sound like Canarias would do whatever I told her, Ciro. Believe me, she has a mind of her own.
Enough! We are fighting a war, and you are intent on fabricating conspiracy when you should be focusing on the real enemy.

Fields.DialogueText: Not yet. A politician must always consider what is and what is possible. If there is a threat to Spain, it must be identified before it becomes a problem, not after!
That is precisely what worries me, Capitán! Canarias is a 13,000 ton warship with a mind of her own. Don't you understand what that could mean?
You are fighting a war, Capitán! I am safeguarding the future of my country! Spain cannot afford to lose her flagship, whether to enemy fire or betrayal.
Enough! Both of you are talking like I am not here! Señor Rosales, I have done everything I can to show my loyalty to España! Why is it not enough?
And Capitán! Do you think I am incapable of fighting my own battles!? Every time you try to defend me, you only make matters worse! I've grown impatient with you both!
Morganas incoming!
@BATTLE
Canarias, I wanted to apologize. I had no intention of making things worse between you and Mr. Rosales.
Por favor, Capitán, I do not want to talk about that right now.
Would you rather I left you alone?
No, I am glad you are here. I am always glad to speak with you, but I cannot think about politics right now.
Very well. What should we talk about?
Have you wondered what it would be like to be a capitán in the past? During the golden age of the sail?
With you as my galleon?
Sometimes I wish I could return to those times. To strip away all the technology and diesel until I just had the direction of the wind and the light of the stars to guide me.

Fields.MenuText: Would you let me guide you as well?
That does sound nice. Perhaps we can go sailing together once this war is over.
As long as I was with you, it wouldn't matter what age I was living in.

Fields.DialogueText: You do guide me, Capitán. You have already helped me find my path more than once.
That does sound like a pleasant thought.
Of course! Who else in history could be my Capitán?
Canarias, remember when you asked me to help you find your future?
I have not forgotten, Capitán. The stars were used to divine the future as well as navigate the oceans. Let us look as them together, just you, me, and the stars.
That's already the future I want.
Capitán?
Never mind. Let's just enjoy the moment.
Capitán, I would like to speak with you.
I'm not sure what we have to discuss, Mr. Rosales.
There is still plenty to discuss. We have been talking around the issue since I got here, but I think it is clear Canarias must make a choice.
Between my command and Spain, or between us, Ciro?
Both, I think. You see me as a threat. As a man who could come between you and your precious Belle. Canarias belongs to Spain! You have no right to her. It is time you let go.
You still don't understand, Ciro. Canarias isn't a slave or a warship. She doesn't belong to me or to Spain.
Ha! If you think you can emancipate our warship, you are sorely mistaken, Capitán. Should I remind you of the fate of the republican capitanes who opposed us?
Is that all she is to you? A warship? You may think I am using my relationship with Canarias to subvert her loyalties to General Franco, but I'm not.
Oh? Why don't you tell me what you are trying to do, Capitán?

Fields.MenuText: I'm not "using” Canarias for anything. I would never use her.
None of your damn business!
I'm not trying to do anything! I'm falling in love with her.

Fields.DialogueText: Wait, don't tell me you... heh. You're not trying to manipulate Canarias, you are in love with her! And here I thought you were a real threat. Ha! My apologizes, Capitán.
You are in love with her! And here I thought you were a real threat. Ha! My apologizes, Capitán.
Wait, don't tell me you... heh. You're not trying to manipulate Canarias, you are in love with her! And here I thought you were a real threat. Ha! My apologizes, Capitán.
What exactly are you apologizing for, Ciro?
Canarias? Were you eavesdropping on a private conversation?
I heard the capitán say, "I would never use her.” Then I heard you laughing.
What exactly are you apologizing for, Ciro?
Canarias? Were you eavesdropping on a private conversation?
Is it none of my business that you talk about me behind my back? Or are you upset because I heard you laughing at me behind my back?
What exactly are you apologizing for, Ciro?
Canarias? Were you eavesdropping on a private conversation?
I could not help but overhear your laughing, Señor Rosales. You were being quite loud.
Please Canarias, I can explain this. You must understand the capitán is misguided...
¡Cállate! You will explain nothing, Señor Rosales. Capitán, I came to find you. We have approaching Morganas we must face.
Let me come with you, and I can...
You can stay right here, Ciro. I do not want you anywhere near my bridge.
@BATTLE
Canarias! We need to talk.
No, Canarias. I must speak with you. Now.
I know. You are both here to tell me I must be loyal to you.
I think it obvious there is only one way we can settle this. The two of you must fight a duel.
A duel!?
Canarias, please. I'm being serious.
So am I. A duel is the only thing that will prove your worthiness and sincerity!
This is preposterous! As representative of the Spanish government, I order you to return to port in Spain as soon as possible. This farce has continued long enough!
¡Excelente! That is a fine demand, Ciro. And you, Capitán? What do you demand of me should you prove the victor?

Fields.MenuText: Are you enjoying yourself, Canarias?
Canarias, you know I wouldn't demand anything of you. I just need to talk to you.
*sigh* All right, fine. I demand you give me your undying affection!

Fields.DialogueText: Immensely, Capitán.
You demand to speak with me then. I shall, provided you best the Señor.
So bold, Capitán! But if you prove the victor, I must accept.
Enough! I have given you a direct order as a representative of your government, Canarias! To disobey me would be treason.
You are here as an observer, Señor Rosales. You have no authority to make demands. My duty is to my Capitán.
Then I will get authority! Spain will receive my report immediately, and then we shall see exactly where both of your loyalties lie!
Well, that's that, I suppose. Canarias, I wasn't going to tell you to be loyal to me... I wanted to explain what Ciro was laughing about.
I know what he was laughing about, Capitán. I was listening from the beginning of your conversation.
Then what was all this about a duel?
Please do not be cross with me, Capitán. It was too much fun to see Ciro's face turn so pale! Do you really think I would need a duel to choose between you?
So... you would choose me?
Of course, Capitán. How could I choose anyone else? But I must admit, it would have been fun to see you beat Ciro senseless.
Canarias, you don't know how happy I am to hear you say that.
We both have much more to say, I imagine, but it must wait for now, Capitán. I have detected Morganas in the area.
@BATTLE
I have just received authorization, Capitán. The Spanish government has given me authority to formally request the return of Canarias from the Protection Force.
Ciro, I know we haven't gotten along, but if you take Canarias now, you will be helping the Morganas win.
Too late, Capitán. Canarias, I hereby order you to return to Spain immediately, where you will be reassigned to the Spanish Fleet.
No.
Did you misunderstand me, Belle? You are under my command now. To disobey is treason.
I would never betray España, Señor Rosales, but if I return with you, I would be allowing the Morganas to conquer Spanish waters. As a patriot, I cannot allow that.
This is not a choice. You have your orders!

Fields.MenuText: You know, legally, I think Ciro might be right, Canarias.
Unlike you, Ciro, Canarias is aware of her duty. She is also aware of when she has a duty to ignore a foolish politician.
I've been waiting for this. Ciro, I think you are about to find out that cannons aren't Canarias' only weapons.

Fields.DialogueText: Gracias, Capitán. I will try to bear that in mind while I beat this fool senseless.
Indeed, my duty and my loyalty is to España. If that means I must become a traitor, so be it.
I still might use my cannons, Capitán. I have not made up my mind yet.
What!? You can't be serious! Listen to me--
No! You will listen to me! I am not a weapon to be bought or a tool to be used. I am a Belle who is capable of making her own choices. I will not follow you!
Traitor!
Lock this man up before I throw him overboard! I will need the radio, Capitán. It seems I must relay a message to España.
Capitán, you have no authority to do this!
Someone get him out of my sight. We have a real war to get back to.
Yes, Captain. Happy to oblige.
@BATTLE
All right, Canarias, I don't know what you said, but I am impressed. Ciro is on a transport back home, and Spain has rescinded their order for your return.
It was simple, Capitán. I gave the Spanish Admiralty a choice. Do as I ask, or lose their most valued warship for the sake of a temperamental diplomat.
You convinced the admiralty to listen to you over Ciro?
I made it clear that Ciro's actions were creating a rift between my duties as a warship and my loyalties to España. Being a Belle seems to give your words a great deal of weight.
Tell me, if you did have to choose between following me and your duty to Spain, which would you pick?
I am not sure, Capitán. I can only say I would follow my heart, and make my own decisions.

Fields.MenuText: What is your heart telling you to do right now?
You know, for a while it seemed like your heart was telling you to be with Ciro.
I would never ask you to betray your country, Canarias. I hope you know that.

Fields.DialogueText: Honestly, I am not sure, Capitán. I think I will need to spend a little time sorting that out.
Do not be jealous, Capitán. I have only had my heart for a little while. You must give me some time to understand it.
Technically, I already betrayed my country for you, Capitán. I hope you know that.
We should get back to the hunt. As long as the Morganas are around, Spain and the rest of the world is under threat.
Sí, Capitán. My duties on that count are clear. Let us send the Brujas del Mar fleeing from these waters! ¡Arriba España!
@BATTLE
It is good to hear your timple again, Canarias, but I'm going to be honest and admit I have no idea who composed that song.
Do not worry, Capitán, I just finished writing it. It is called "Por Baleares.”
It is beautiful. I think it sounds sad, but also hopeful.
There has been so much going on lately that we haven't had the chance to sit and speak, Capitán. There are some things I wish to say.

Fields.MenuText: You have my full attention.
Yeah, I feel like I'm still not sure where we stand exactly. I mean, I'm happy to be with you, but I want to know what that means for both of us.
Me first. I love you, Canarias.

Fields.DialogueText: When I overheard Ciro laughing at you, I wanted to laugh as well. Not to mock you like he did, but because hearing you loved me filled my heart with joy.
I had always thought of you as my Capitán, but when I heard that you felt more for me, I realized that was what I wanted more than anything.
Capitán...here I have all these things to say to you, and you leave me speechless.
So, do we wait for the war to end, or do we try and make this work now?
I am still a Belle, Capitán. This will probably not be my last war. Besides, I do not think I will be able to be patient, now that I know my heart's desire.
All right, I think I can live with that.
You had better!
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Lovely timing, Morganas!
More Morganas for my guns to pierce!
@BATTLE
Canarias, you look amazing! How did you clean up so quickly after the battle?
I wanted to look my best for you, Capitán. It is only right.

Fields.MenuText: You know, I like you regardless of how you're dressed.
You are beautiful, Canarias. I thought so the very first time I saw you.
You realize this means another round of Morganas is going to attack us any time now.

Fields.DialogueText: I'd say the same to you, Capitán.
It might have taken me a little longer to warm up to you…
Ha! I think they do have some sort of inferiority complex.
Have you given any thought to our future?
I still do not know what my future will be, Capitán, but so long as you are with me, that is all the future I need.
I love you, Canarias.
Te quiero también, Capitán.
Ha! That doesn't surprise me in the least.
